review.title: Detecting Road Surface Wetness from Audio: A Deep Learning Approach
review.abstract: We introduce a recurrent neural network architecture for automated road surface wetness detection from audio of tire-surface interaction. The robustness of our approach is evaluated on 785,826 bins of audio that span an extensive range of vehicle speeds, noises from the environment, road surface types, and pavement conditions including international roughness index (IRI) values from 25 in/mi to 1400 in/mi. The training and evaluation of the model are performed on different roads to minimize the impact of environmental and other external factors on the accuracy of the classification. We achieve an unweighted average recall (UAR) of 93.2% across all vehicle speeds including 0 mph. The classifier still works at 0 mph because the discriminating signal is present in the sound of other vehicles driving by. Removing audio segments at speeds below 2.9 mph from consideration improves the UAR to 100%. In the case when the vehicle speed is below 2.9 mph, we were able to discriminate between wet and dry road surfaces from ambient noises and achieve 74.5% UAR.

sections.text: In addition, the number of weather-related accidents in the United States exceeds 380,000 injuries and 4,700 deaths per year [1]. In addition, wet roads often increase traffic congestion and lead to infrastructure damage and disruptions in the supply chain [2]. However, from a driving safety perspective, detecting wetness during the post-occurrence period is critical whether the road is still wet. In these conditions, human assessment of road moisture and friction properties is less accurate than normal, especially in the form of reduced visibility overnight or in the presence of fog [3]. Automated detection of road conditions from audio can be an important component of the next generation of Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS), which have the potential to improve driver safety.

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Long-term memory RNNs (LSTM-RNNs) have been successfully used in many areas, from handwriting recognition to robotic heart surgery [6]. In the audio context, LSTM-RNNs have contributed to the development of a better phoneme classification, which impacts on the recognition of animal species and the search for the temporal structure in music [8]. However, to the best of our knowledge, LSTM-RNs have not been applied to the task of road humidity. Related work can be found in video processing, where humidity was examined with two camera settings. (1) A surveillance camera at night, and (2) a camera on board a vehicle. Detection of the road surface using night surveillance cameras that rely on passing cars.

sections.heading: A. Contribution
sections.text: The method described in our paper improves the predictive accuracy of the method presented in [5] and extends the evaluation to a wider range of surface types and road conditions. In addition, this study is the first to apply LSTM RNs in this area. In addition, we improve the following three aspects of [5] where (1) the model was trained and tested on the same road segment, (2) incorrect predictions caused by the impact of pebbles on the vehicle chassis were ignored, and (3) audio segments associated with speeds below 18.6 km / h were removed. We trained and tested the model on different routes and took into account all predictions regardless of speed, impact of pebbles or any other factor.

sections.heading: III. ROAD SURFACE WETNESS CLASSIFICATION

sections.heading: A. Data Collection
sections.text: For data collection purposes, we instructed a 2014 Mercedes CLA with a cost-effective shotgun microphone behind the rear tire, as shown in Fig. 2. The amplification level of the microphone and its distance from the tire were kept the same throughout the data collection process, selecting three different routes for each route, one during the rain (or immediately after) and another time when the road surface was completely dry, as shown in Fig. 3. We offer spectrograms in Fig. 4 for wet and dry sections of the same route, highlighting the difference in frequency behavior. Duration and length of trips ranged from 14 minutes to 30 minutes, or 6.1 miles to 9.0 miles. sections.heading: B. Features
sections.text: Our goal was to model the entire spectrum along with the differences of the first order and then select a subset of characteristics that best distinguishes our classes. We extracted auditory spectral characteristics (ASF) [13], which were calculated by applying the short-term Fourier transformation (STFT) using a frame size of 30 ms and a frame step of 10 ms. Furthermore, each STFT power spectrogram was converted into the Mel frequency scale using 26 triangular filters obtained by the Mel spectrograms M30 (n, m). To do justice to human perception of loudness, a logarithmic representation was chosen: M30log (n, m) = protocol (M 30 (n, m) + 1.0). (1) In addition, the positive first order differences M30 (n, m) were calculated from a comparison of loudness (n, m).

sections.heading: C. Classifier
sections.text: In this paper, we used a deep learning approach with initialized meshes - LSTM and bidirectional LSTM (BLSTM) RNN architectures, which unlike other RNNN do not suffer from the problem of disappearing gradients [32]. BLSTM is an extension of the LSTM architecture, which allows additional forward speed when a predictive buffer can be used, which has proven itself in many applications [8]. In addition, we evaluated various parameters, such as the layout of LSTM and BLSTM hidden layers (54-54, 54-30-54, 156-256-156, 216-216-216-216-216 neurons in the three hidden layers) and learning rates (1e-4, 1e-5, 1e-6). Initially, we chose a deep architecture with three hidden layers of the same size as input vectors (54), before grading their properties and examining the next layer's internal effectiveness.

sections.heading: IV. RESULTS
sections.text: Table II shows the evaluation results in an ascending order for the best 20 characteristics selected with IG (IG-20), as described in § III-B, and as trained with LSTM-RNNs. We present only the worst three and the best three results for RNNs, while other experiments are excluded from the table. Furthermore, an average validation for all three folds from Table I was calculated.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: We proposed an in-depth learning approach based on LSTM-RNNs for detecting road moisture using audio recordings of tire-surface interaction and distinguishing between wet and dry classes. This method proves to be robust in terms of vehicle speed, road type and road surface quality on a 785,826 record. It surpasses the most advanced SVMs and achieves outstanding performance in the task of detecting road moisture with a VAR of 93.2% for all vehicle speeds and the more challenging speeds below 2.9 km / h, including stationary vehicle mode. In future work, we will expand the functionality for assessing road water depth and detecting hydroplanic conditions.ABDIC ́ et al.: DETECTING ROAD SURFACE WETNESS FROM AUDIO: A DEEP LEARNING APROPACH 5
